I love this beer. Thick, dark body, off white head, light fizz. Chocolate, coffee and caramel flavour. Delicious. I want more.

Pours dark, dark brown with a medium macchiato tan head. Smells ..chocolate/coffee/malt, dark fruits, some woody/old hops and a bit of booze when it warms up. Tastes choc/coffee/malt into cured salty / sour dark fruits (when warmer) which is balanced by a malty coffee sweetness and some roast action+ bitterness to finish. Pleasure.

500ml bottle at BrewDog,Birmingham shared with Steve.10th march.This was a nice looking black pour with a short lived tan head.Mainly chocolate nose at first but other aromas appeared after a little warming including a little smokiness and vanilla.Taste of dark chocolate,coffee and vanilla with some booze.Balanced and smooth drinking tasty porter.Last part of drink especially nice after a little more warming.

bottle.  deep brown body with a small light brown ring of a head and little retention.  simple, inky, dark chocolate is the first impression of the nose, though theres some char (notes of liquid smoke and soy sauce are coming up) and light esters (plum, date, black cherry, dark fruits, etc.) that show up with time, but altogether the nose seems a bit plain and one-dimensional (a lot of chocolate syrup).  low carbonation, medium-high body which dissolves late into a medium-thin finish.  medium-low bitterness and low acid, light to moderate roasted grain astringency, though much cleaner than most of the De Proef Mikkeller beers, I have to agree with others.  not too sweet, decent roast character with some mild malted milk ball notes and a touch of green hops (pine and a little bell pepper).  overall its a well-made strong porter but I wonder if a little more carbonation could give it a little more expression to those dark fruit esters and give the body a little more roundness and froth.

Bottle picked up at Zyn in Calgary Alberta. Pours pitch black with dark tan head that is a ring, flecks of lacing. Nose is so sweet and inviting. Roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and vanilla, maybe a touch of coffee. Tastes like dark chocolate, cold coffee, boozy with a bit of bite. Vanilla smooth. Nice silky mouthfeel.
Pours pitch black with a brown head. Nose of mild chocolate. Aroma is direct, chocolate and coffee. Well balanced, and smooth. A great porter.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a large, frothy and bubbly tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee and roast malt with earthy and herbal hops, figs, dates, and prunes.  Flavor is malt dominant with dark fruity esters, light hops and medium bitterness with a dry finish.  Full body and medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with thick, frothy tan head; good retention and spare lacing. Aroma is roasted and caramel malts, milk chocolate, plums, coffee, earthy hops, and light toast. Flavor is roast malt forward with supporting dark fruit esters, light chocolate, coffee, light ash, and some earthy hops; dry, roast finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle 50cl, a dark beer with brown head. nose is very chocolate and creamy like. Aroma is on dark chocolate, dark malt, coffee, caramel, toffee, light ashes, very creamy with some wood / vanilla touch and licorice notes, very pleasant, good porter.

Holy cow! Pours deep brown, deep cola. Little carbonation that provides a slight tan halo that leaves loose lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, a bit of soy sauce and stone fruits. Taste is equally complex. Lots of the same notes with a bit of brown sugar and finishes a bit dry. A chocolate taste lingers for awhile. At $5.99 a bottle wish Id bought more!

500 ml bottle from Sams Quik Shop for a cool $5.99. Pours black with just a bit of light through the edges. Light brown head at first but not much more after. Nose shows a marshmallow lactose that complexifies the more expected roast, coffee, and chocolate notes. Some mineral notes. Also some stone fruits. Taste adds a bit of sweet and bitter. Palate is chalky dry. So much going on here. Really quite lovely.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is black (opaque, flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (coffee, roasted grain, dark chocolate, caramel), with light notes of tar, cassis, juniper leaves.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

FINALLY, a good Mikkeller beer.  I expected this to be another drain pour, but thats definitely not the case.  I must assume this is because this was brewed at Amager instead of the abysmal De Proef.  Indeed, thats the only reason I bought this, and thankfully its surprisingly good.  Rich malt character, very coffee-ish and enticing.  Reminds me a bit of Amagers own Rye Porter, in fact.  None of the usual dirty De Proef off notes, quite clean and enjoyable to drink.  Its ultimately too expensive and sweet-and-boozy for me to buy again, but I quite enjoyed this.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2015 8%. 500ml bottle at home. Pours black with a fine, coffee-cream, long-lasting head. Inviting aroma of roast malts and caramel, some dark fruits. Taste has a lovely balance of bitter and sweet, like memory of playing with a childhood friend you?re no longer in touch with. More coffee and roast flavours, some sweetness. Full-bodied, but not too rich, Lovely smooth finish. One of the best.

A - Dark black with a touch of brown and a finger of frothy khaki colored head.Fades fairly slowly.

S - Roasted chocolate and caramel malts, black licorice, molasses, vanilla, coffee, some earthy hops.

T - Roasted dark chocolate and caramel malts, black licorice, molasses, roasted coffee, cofffee bitterness, vanilla, some earthy hops and mild bitterness.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a roasted, dry, and sweet finish.

D - Nice strong porter. Great overall balance.

Beer on tap at the Underground called "Mikkeller American Porter" but i asume its this one since all the stats line up. Black brown body, long lasting tan cap. First sniff is nothing but coffee. First sip is chocolate with a coffee finish. Back to the aroma..... almost milk chocolate but not really plus coffee that is all. Taste is close to same. Im enjoying the fact that this beer dosnt seem to have any gimmik to it, no fancy aging, no random ingrediant, its just a porter. Very easy to drink, goes down scarey fast. Crap my food has arived and all I smell now is clam chowder. Sweet taste, mild ash in finsh, I will say prunes. Good beer the 8% is completly hidden, goes down fast. The very simple noncomplex tatse is what I like best about this beer.

Draft at Beer Temple.  Pours black with a beige head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, caramel, some dark fruit and a little vanilla.  Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  Simply a great example of the style.

Just a porternothing crazy or experimental, no catch nor gimmick with this one :) Although brewed unfortunately at Amager Bruyghus of whom I am not the biggest fan. 50 cl. bottle consumed @ Delirium Hoppy Loft where it seemingly sarcastically refers to the initial remark which I lovingly got there by being called Porter Porter on the menu. Another Keith Shore design, meh  this kind of nouveau, post-kitsch pop art stuff doesnt really appeal to me as usual. Pours a serious black with a non-lasting towering mocha head. Smell is vinous coffee mixed with heavy burned coffee grounds, strong roast, viscous, somewhat boozy. Taste is bitter coffee grounds, bitter vinous coffee, very strong bitter coffee grounds, raw, liquorice, touch herbs, grounded coffee, touch mocha, burned toast, touch hops & booze in the back. Vinous, sludge melted mocha ice-cream mouthfeel. Reminds me a bit of the impression that Gonzo once made on me which was the first beer of its kind of me & the beer that got me into the whole thing. Raw & over the edge, this is way less than that memory made Gonzo out to be but it does make me think back. Not too bad.

500ml bottle. Black Coffee Colour, thin tan head that doesnt last. At the end you see elements of proteins or yeast. Aroma is roasty, burnt and woody. Medium sweet taste, roasty with subtle notes of hops. Easy to drink despite the 8% ABV. Really nice and smooth Porter.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 500ml bottle- feels and looks bigger somehow. Glossy tar pour topped with a deep grey-tan mousse. Aroma of chipshop batter, plum, palinka, slight toast and prunes. Thick, black custard mouthfeel; notes of iron, schwarz, blackcurrant, Twiglet. Light burnt bitterness to finish. Sugar puff sweetness bittered, burnt and smeared with plum/blueberry. Some charred almond and black cherry hinting at the ABV. Fine porter.

500ml bottle pours almost black in color with a finger and a half of light brown head that retains well and leaves some spotty lacing on the glass.  Aroma is roasted grains and chocolate with some dark fruits and a hint of brown sugar.  Taste is chocolate and brown sugar sweetness with a little tartness from the dark fruits and a roasted grain and hop bitterness in the finish.  More malt forward, but still decently balanced and quite a tasty porter.

Bottle at home (BOE) 24/12/12.
Pours mid black with a frothy tan head that clears to a bubbly edge and leaves a swirl of a film atop the glass.
Nose is roast malts, milk chocolate, a little vanilla and a touch of dark fruits and sugars.
Taste comprises roast malt, chocolate, touch of coffee, molasses. maltesers, hint of liqourice.
Full end of medium bodied, fine carbonation, fairly smooth on the palate a little roasty bitterness in the finish.
Decent stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours a beautiful dark brown with a light brown head.  Coffee, roast, and licorice in the aroma.  Flavor has coffee, chocolate, vanilla, roast.  Roast coffee bitterness, smoke, and alcohol in the finish.  This is an outstanding sipper.

500ml bottle. Pitch black color. Medium size head appears, diminishes to small head rather quickly. Coffee, roast, plums, creamy, oily, malty notes in aroma. Buttery, roast, coffee, chocolate, alcohol in flavor. Nice juicy roast in aftertaste. Slightly crisp.

50 cl bottle @ home. Pours dark brown with some sediment and a tan head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, liquorice, and subtle smoke. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, and liquorice.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a very thick head. A little bit bitter, with a fair amount of roasting in the nose. Taste has a little bit of coffee in it with just a hint of sour. Interesting...
Bottle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, milk chocolate, coffee, licorice, smoky notes, hints of nuts, and hops. Nice and dry finish. Awesome.
Süß röstiger Beginn, Espresso. Vollmundig, Intensive Röstaromen, harmonisch. Malzig bleibend, die süße geht etwas zurück. Stimmiges rundes Bier, rundum gelungen. 12/12/12/12/8/12

Bottle. Pours black with a dark brown head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has a good amount of roasted malts with a bit of bitter chocolate and a hint of dryness. Flavor starts with strong roasted malt note with a slight bitter chocolate note with a light lactose in the finish.

500 ml bottle. Very dark brown, almost black. Medium tan head. Sweet and roasty aroma with a bit of "black marker tip" smell. Heavy and robust taste of roasted malt and chocolate. Some ash in the otherwise sweet finish. The sweetness is kind of over the top, just like in Black Hole... Is that Heisenberg on the label?

50cl. bottle at home. Pitch black and has dense but brief light brown head. Smells very nice. Very full bodied and feels sweet and smooth. Taste is like roasted coffee and chocolate. Perhaps a bit of plum too. A very good porter.

Bottle at home. Black color, temptating smooth light brown head. Aroma of plum, chocolate, coffee. Smooth and nice mouthfeel, strong taste of chocolate, coffee, roasty, little hops at the end. Balanced, good body.

500ml bottle (Drink Shop, Tallinn)
Pours dark, and with a brief tight tan head that settles to a ring. Some clear estery spikes immediately after pouring, not so fruity, more solventy, but not in a particularly bad way, I wish I could think of a better word than solvent. On settling, the aroma becomes mashier, almost oatmealy, but of source strongly pointing in the roasted direction. In the mouth, immediately the same esters come over quickly with quite a kick up the back of the mouth and nose. Roast follows swiftly afterwards. Fairly pleasant rich roast, but alas an ashy burntness takes over and dominates. Some nice full-flower hops, I wouldnt be surprised if they were english, as theyre quite dry and earthy, perhaps a bit nettley too. However, that could just be the effect of the burntness. Smooth palate, pleasant carbonation. Alcohol restrained, but still noticeable. Too ashy for my taste, drinkability not so high. Felt Id had enough of it after 100ml, but certainly didnt want to waste it. Anna doesnt get is so burnt, but does get more alcohol, and more chocolatiness. Later sips show off the hops a bit better, quite a zingy spiciness coming across in the mouth. Pretty OK, but Id never exchange any BGB for one of these. Stop Press: as it warms (one QI episode later), there are more hops, and the body becomes sweeter, and that pushes the ashiness back quite a bit. So I do actually like having this in my mouth, and will pop the palate from 3 to 4.

Very dark brown, almost black, tan head with filmy retention. Nose is malt, coffee, burned sugar, hoppy notes in the background. Taste is pretty complex - milk chocolate, dried fruit, licorice, malt, caramel. Bitter roasty finish with a somewhat boozy bite. Oily mouthfeel, flat carbonation, medium to full body. Nice balance.

Big massive beer, lovely. Pours oily black with a small tan head that dissipates to a ring. Minimal lacing. Nose is burnt coffee and bitter chocolate. Aromas are same, as well as a hint of dark fruit in the background and lots of bitter espresso. Mouthfeel is oily with lively carbonation. Tastes are big sweet and a huge bitter finish. Great stuff.

Pours a thick oily black with creamy tan head. Smell is of malt, caramel, burnt roasted coffee.
Taste very smooth and silky, not unlike Geek Breakfast. Roasted malts and chocolate taste.
Very very good. 8% and its an easy drinker!

Bottled. Pours an opaque black with a small tan head leaving a fair lacing. Nose of roasted malt and dark fruit notes. Sweet flavor with coffee, chocolate, plums, toasted malt and licorice that ends up more dry and slightly bitter. Medium to full bodied, oiy texture and soft carbonation. Excellent.

Bottle. Black with tidy light brown head. Thick malty aroma, dark chocolate and licorice, some dark fruits, plum. Taste has a more roasty flavour, ashy, chocolate and fruity licorice. Perhaps a little thin with some sweetness and a slightly bitter finish. Very tasty

Bottle @ Home. Pours black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, vanilla, cherries. Flavor is malts, coffee, light smoke, red cherries, milk chocolate. Medium to full body, silky mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Very nice porter. 161012

Bottle. Nice aroma of vanilla, roated malt and dark chocolate. VEry dark brown colour with small light brown head. Rather swwet flavour of malt mixed with cofee, chocolate and vanilla. Soft and pleasant mothfeel. No reason for shooting as indicated on the lbel. Relax and enjoy instead.
Fra fat på Ørsted: aroma av kraftig røstet malt. Lite skum. Behagelig karbonert/munnfylde. Kirsebær, kaffe og ristet brød i smaken. Lang ettersmak med behagelig bitterhet.

16.9 oz bottle. Love Mikkeller, thought Id give their porter a shot. Pours an almost completely opaque black with a large billowing dark tan head. Smells of cherries, malt, a bit of roastedness, smoke, and some chocolate. Taste is sweet malt, some smoke flavor, and light chocolate. Good body for a porter, epitome of the right palate for one. Very good porter overall.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 Tap at Ørsted Ølbar. My Mikkeller rating #100. Very dark brown, reddish hue, small coffeebrown head. Peculiar cherry-scented sweet malty nose. Flavor is sweet malty, light roast, chocolate, sweet spicy vanilla, bitter finish. Nice and very drinkable, but kinda odd.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aromas of sweet malt, chocolate and a hint of cherries. A dark brown pour with a mostly lasting tan head and nice lacing. This is, overall, a sweet porter. Chocolate is the predominate taste. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, while an enjoyable porter, it is sweeter than I normale like. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Subtle, refined and balanced. Creamy chocolate and coffee nuances, with a mild bittersweet note and touch of smoke. Simple, yet well made. Smooth mouthfeel, with expansive, silky carbonation. Good, not great.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Very dark brown, very creamy and lasting tan head. Very creamy, chocolate covered raisins, dark fruits and humous. Very smooth rich taste, great amount of flavour. Very impressed. So nice to see a plain, un experimental beer from Mikkeller some time. And its awesome! (At the De Molen tasting)

50cl bottle at the molen monthly tasting.
Small tan head.
Clear dark pour.  Chocolate in the aftertaste. Very smooth.  Very nice brew.

Huge chocolate nose pretty much dictates everything that comes thereafter. . . but the thereafter is a really excellent version of "the classic porter."

Might be a little on the stout side of porter-- all the oatmealiness and cocosity you could want-- but the really nice dry finish, and clean sweet notes really make it work.  

I wouldnt have liked it if the mouth feel were any thicker, or the consistency any more syrupy but the balance here is really impressive, for such a smokey, malty porter.  Glad to finally get a "dark" beer from Mikkeller that lives up to the reputation-- very excellent porter, this one.

Poured a bit too cold with a smallish, thick, tan head that soon settled and some lace. Color is an opaque black brown. Aroma is an aromatic malt, roast, dark ripe fruit, cocoa. Flavors much like nose, bittersweet up front followed by mild carbonic tang. Body is good, but carbonation seems a tad flat. Finish is very long and boozy. All taken together it leaves me without much desire for another .5 liter bottle.
Bottle shared amongst friends. Very much like a typical imperial porter, no thrills. Chocolate and malts up front with a hint of peanuts on the back end.

On tap at Friscoe Grille & Taproom in Columbia, MD.  

Opaque, near black with 2-finger brown head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of chocolate, coffee and smiley roasted malt. 

Taste of sweet, rich chocolate, roasted coffee, molasses and dark roasted malt. 

Medium/full body and medium/light carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
150712: Black Porter from Mikkeller which is brewed in Amager brewery. Nice light brown foam. Lovely chocolate flavor.

500 ml bottle from The Wine and Cheese Place. Pours an opaque coffee brown with a massive, frothy tan head that laces the glass. Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, earth, nuts, dark fruits, and toasted sugar. Flavor of dark chocolate, fudge, wood, earth, tobacco, and nuts. Medium-bodied, with medium-high carbonation and a roasty, drying, bitter mouthfeel. Just a wee bit abrasive on the palate, but otherwise a solid porter.
What a great porter.  Highly roasted and nutty with great deep chocolate and malty flavors.  Starts sweet and finishes dry and flavorful.  Full bodied and fantastic A+.

Bottle. Pours with a black hued body with a very large brown head. Good retention and very good lace. Head slowly recedes (not much). Aromas are very floral, pine, cocoa powder. Lots of bready malt, nutty, dark bakers chocolate. Woody and earthy. Flavors are ashy, bitter, a touch acrid. Roast is a bit harsh for my tastes (personal preference with black malt and roasted barley). Some nuttiness. Dry. Some acidity to the roast. Malty, nutty, toasted, biscotti flavors. Some vanilla flavors, floral hops. Medium to medium light bitterness. Roasty balance. Medium to slightly fuller carbonation. Medium dry, a bit fuller bodied. Light mineral or carbonic bite towards the end. Very good, not really sure it is how take a porter. Its pretty solid, but Im not in love with it. Well crafted though.
Great malty roasty aroma. Delicious malts. Mikkeller can really make an awesome Danish dark beer! Cheers!!

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown body, almost black, with a nice one inch foamy brown head that retained as a thin covering.  The nose is roast and chocolaty with a slight hint of citrusy hops.  Very thick and robust aroma.  The chocolate has a real nice dark cocoa quality.  The flavor leans toward the roast more than chocolate, almost like bakers chocolate what is there.  Comes across rather bitter and burnt.  The finish is long and slightly acrid.  Mouthfeel is a bit overly carbonated for my tastes, but the body is nicely thick and chewy.  There are certain aspects of this that I like, but on the overall its fairly average.

500 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours pitch black color with a nice 3 finger fairly dense tan head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some nice spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, toast, earth, herbal, bread, caramel, tobacco, and light apple skin fruitiness.  Some pretty nice aromas with good strength and balance; but the apple skins throw it off a bit.  Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malt, toast, caramel, vanilla, coffee, cream, herbal, earth, and light char.  Light roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, coffee, cream, and light char on the finish for a good bit.   Very nice balance of flavors that are quite robust; with a nice malty backbone that is not cloying at all.  Medium carbonation and body; with a very creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice anf straightforward robust porter.  Very nice robust and balanced flavors, and extremely easy to sip on.  Only knock I have against it is the slightly off aromas.  Very enjoyable stuff.

Bottled 500ml (Beer Hunters)
Almost opaque brown color, small steady brown head. Strong chocolate-cocoa aroma. Medium-bodied. Chocolate, toasted malts, sweet malts, chocolate bisquits. Very tasty with Amager fingerprints in it.

Pours blackish brown, thin dense ring of sandy head. Nose is roasted malts, anise, coffee, milk chocolate, pine. Same flavors on the palate but it's simply bolder and really tasty. Could drink this on a consistent basis.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance:  syrupy near-black pour with caramel brown edges, with a creamy, silky tan head that lasts and lasts.   Aroma: roasty dark malts, a bit of coffee, some chocolate, anise, licorice, and molasses.   Taste: coffee, bitter dark chocolate, licorice, a hint of plums or prunes, with a nice shot of green stick/piney resinous hops.   Finish: bitter, a little tangy (lactic), with lingering roasty dryness and earthy, piney hops.   Notes: Great porter.  Palate was a revelation of creamy smoothness.  Flavors were bold.

16.9 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown with an inch frothy tan head.  The head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  The brew smells like roasted malt, anise, molasses, dark fruit, and some coffee and chocolate.  It tastes like roasted malt, anise, dark fruit (mostly grapes), molasses, nuts and coffee.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and smooth and pretty easy to drink.  I think its a good overall porter, although I think its fruitier than most porters Ive had.  Id pick this one up again.  $9.99 a bottle at Party Town.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a large sized tan head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, and lighter coffee. Tastes of chocolate, roast, coffee, and some anise.
Pours deep mahogany into a Sam glass. Mocha head with excellent retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Smoky sweet chocolate aromas. Sharp with dark pit fruit, chocolate and espresso.

Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, roasted, slate, chocolate and some licorice. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall this is a good beer.
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and light chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, liquorish and light chocolate.

(bottle) Black body with a medium, frothy brown head. Dark malty aroma; molasses, chocolate, some dark fruit, light coffee. Fully bodied, thick texture, slight carbonation. Flavor is medium to heavy sweet, caramel, dark roasted malt, dark chocolate, liquorice; medium and lasting bitter finish.

500mL bottle, pours black with a large foamy tan head. Aroma is quite roasty for a porter with roasted malt upfront, dark cocoa powder, some feint metallic / rubber notes, and espresso buried in there. Flavour is quite sweet, with caramel, bittersweet dark cocoa, subtle licorice, and finishes somewhat sweet and somewhat metallic / rubbery - loses some of its enjoyability on that finish. Solid porter though nothing special.
Bottle. black colour with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, hop, licorice, pine. Flavour is coffee, chocolate, pine, roasted malt, hop, licorice. Full body. Very nice beer.
bottle.  Pour is dark with a light brown head.  Aroma is rich with malts that screams porter.  Taste is smooth and the malt continues, but less than what the smell indicates.  Finishes nice as well.

Bottle from Binnys. Pours a translucent deep brown with a dissipating offwhite head. Nose is chocolate and some floral hopping. Kind of odd, expected a bit roast character. Moderately sweet in the nose as well. On tasting, really quite bitter and a roast character comes through. Moderate level of sweetness. A bit thin bodied overall as well, unfortunately. Tasty enough with a good hop flavor but just is lacking overall in depth and body.

Bottle from The Davis Beer Shoppe in Davis, CA. Pours very dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is strongly chocolate, almost obscuring some dark toasted malt. Full bodied. Its chocolate, smooth dark toast malt, with some anise, and Im pretty sure theres coffee in the finish. Its a complex little thing - finishes dry, chocolate and arguably astringent with light anise.

Bottle picked up at Drowlands old stomping grounds, the Cedar Falls Hy-Vee Wine and Spirits, I assume this odd and awesome availability is the work of HeyKevin, Mikkeller on shelves in Cedar Falls... never thought Id see the day. 

Pours black with a big tan head that fades to a small tight head that manages to leave a nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is roasty and woody, earthy and lightly boozy, and featuring a nice little black currant fruitiness just for good measure. 

The flavor is very roasty and on the drier side of the style. The bitterness is prevalent throughout and is very enjoyable. Some more of that currant shows up in the flavor and it works nicely with the general earthy character and hop flavor of the beer. I really liked the flavor of this beer and I would have scored it even higher but there was this light tinge of medicinal character in the finish that was mildly annoying and off putting, but beyond that this was a very nice beer and not what I expected from a Mikkeller Imperial Porter.

Bottle.  Pour is deep dark porter- brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is rich roasted malt, Carmel, faint molasses, and a touch of coffee.  Flavor is very true to nose with the malt being a little smoother than the aroma would suggest. Flavor is pure porter. Light roasted malt, faint hop, and a touch of sweet coffee.  Great porter.

Bottle. Black pour with a medium, frothy brown head. Aroma is roasted malt with tart fruit, soy sauce, light coffee and faint chocolate. Taste is tart with lactic notes, sour milk/yogurt, roasted malt, soy sauce, faint chocolate, and licorice. Body is medium but acidic with soft, prickly bubbles. Dry through the finish. Ends with dark fruit, sour chocolate milk, roasted malt, tart fruit, soy sauce, bitter coffee, licorice, burnt caramel and steak sauce. Not really my cup of tea or that pleasant of a beer. Too sour, bitter and acidic too much of the time.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, roasting, light coffee, ash, and dust.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, tan/beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, roasting, hops, light licorice, light chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  Medium body.  Coating, slick, then dry and lightly chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, roast, coffee, light licorice, finish is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Ah porter...  If only it were fresh.  Like many imported beverages I can see the promise of this brew that resides behind a wall of papery hop oxidation and a lightly astringent finish from darkly roasted husks.  Pours a deep mahogany with aromas of chocolate, roasted coffee and fusels.  A perfectly smooth and rounded body lends forth flavors of chocolate, plums, a hint of citrus, and a finish of pineapple, iron and cardboard.  I bet this beer kicks some serious ass in Denmark.
Draugt at Cask & Kitchen. Full flavour, roast, toast smoke. Fruit blackcurrant, dry finish, excellent beer.

Bottled. Poured cola brown with a tall cap of khaki head. The aroma picked up fairly sweet and quite roasty coffee, with hints of vanilla and cola deeper down.. fresh, greener hops accented well, but there was something missing. The flavor found more near-burnt black patent than anything else, but it kept a lot of the coffee.. soy and licorice joined toward the back.. green hops surrounded again.. tasty.  Medium-bodied, very roasty, and a little sour on the palate.. a little more overt prickly boozage than I wanted on the back.. OK overall feel and flow.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a surprising thick and foamy tan head.  Nose is coffee, prune, cola, caramel and cocoa.  Medium body quickly thinned with zippy carb.  Taste is chocolate syrup, espresso, licorice and molasses.  Near perfect porter that happens to be imperial.

Black with big, foamy, brown head / Complex, toasty, nose of chocolate, coffee, biscuit, and licorice / Medium body, chewy but overly acidic, but still with good balance.  Acidity detracts from very bitter finish / Flavors dont match the promise of the nose, with astringent notes of dark roast coffee, banana, and grass / Lots of promise, but flawed.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoke and coffee. Flavor is chocolate with cola notes. Medium body, dry finish.

Bottle courtesy of Jesse.  Thanks!  Black with a fizzy tan head.  Sweet herbal and citrus aroma with notes of roasted grain.  Tastes of chocolate, banana, roasted grain and light drip coffee.  Medium bodied, smooth, bright palate.
Very earthy malts in aroma.  The flavor is coffee,caramel, a decent hoppiness but not overly so and fruit.  A great porter, excellent.

Poured from the bottle. Nice tan creamy head very prevalent while enjoying. Aroma is great roasty, chocolate, I do detect cherries. In the flavor as well. Very good espresso like flavor. This is a great porter, Ive only had a handful of great porters, and this is one! Palate was thick and oily finish.

Expensive $12 bottle I bought at Sams Quik Shop based on GT2s rating.  This better be good.  Pour is pretty much black with a thin tan head that lasts. It smells very roasty and full, mild cocoa notes, some espresso, light cherry skins.   Taste is also full, some more roast, some sweeter cocoa, light coffee/espresso.  Kinda similar to the Nogne Porter the first I had it, but this one has a much fuller body.  Alcohol is hardly noticed.  Best Mikkeller beer Ive had in quite some time.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, black with great roasty chocolate, raisin and molasses notes but the body on this is the silkiest smoothest I have ever tasted
pours black with a brown head. Aroma is cocoa and ash. Flavor is chocolate and roasted malt. Finishes very balanced and thin!

Sampled at SuperBowl 46.  Black pour with layer of light brown head.  Extremely bitter roastedness is the biggest note from this.  Dark chocolate, burnt, drying bitterness, almost chalky, on the tail, but upfront sweetness.  Not one of my favorites from Mikkeller.
Molt cremosa i molta xocolata. Lleugera i fàcil de beure. Molt interessant per començar a iniciar-se amb negres.
Shared Bottle at Beer Revolution. This is a great porter. nice dark malt taste. color is black. with a brownish head. Mikkeller makes some great  beers

(500ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a spare tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, some ash, and Deet.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, and caramel with a dry, moderately bitter finish.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. The taste is roast, coffee, malts, burnt, and chocolate. The smell is roast, chocolate, coffee, malts, and burnt. The look is reddish color, thin no head, and dark.
Deep brown with a small head. Aroma is of heavy dark chocolate and roasted malts. Rich dark chocolate taste with some coffee, and espresso.

Bottle. Pours a very deep brown with dense milk coffee colloured head. Nice fine lacing as the head slowly feely away. Aromas of roasted hazelnuts and dark chocolate dominate support by roasted grains, milk coffee and some earthy hops. Feint hint of sourness from the grains I suspect to wrap everything together. Brilliant. Flavours dont disappoint either. Flavours show lots of bittersweet chocolate, milk coffee, roasted grains and spice. Full oily silky smooth mouthfeel. Brilliant beer

Bottle @ home. Deep brown appearance with a fluffy, brown head. Big roasty, dark chocolate malty, a touch nutty, light espresso aroma. Exquisite nose. Huge, burnt, roasty, chocolate malty, a touch smoky, cocoa, mild coffee flavor. One of my new favorites from these guys. Very nice beer.

500ml bottle shared with buds over the holidays. Poured into a snifter a deep chocolate with a thick creamy head. Nose is roasted malts,licorice, cocoa and hints of coffee. Taste is caramel and malts. Has some sweet chocolate and dark fruits on the finish. Smooth mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Nice.

Pitch dark black body with a small brown head. Strong aroma of bitter coffee and licorice. Full body, little carbonation. Strong coffee and black chocolate in the flavour with some smoke and vanilla as well. Excellent.

500mL. Pours a clear sepia to deep cola with a towering, thick, beige head. Tight bubbled retention. 360 sheety to webby lace. Nose is rich hazelnut, amaretto, toasted nuts, spicy dark chocolate, spicy resinous hops. Taste up front is a bit funky moving to rich roast and heavy semisweet chocolate and spicy soaked black cherries. Hugely silky palate. Wow- ultra thick for style. Very enjoyable. A wavers1 beer for sure! Reminds me a lot of Amager Imperial Stout aesthetics wise. I actually went out and bought this after reading drowlands rating and boy am I glad I did. Thanks Dr. Owland!
Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours black with a thick tan head and a treacle aroma. There is an intense chocolate and coffee flavor with a dry finish. Very tasty.
Bottle. Pours black with dark brown head. Nose/taste of heavily roasted barley, roast chocolate malt, lightly smoked black malt, vanilla and roasted coffee. Medium body.

Pours black with a small khaki head. Coffee, chocolate and a lot of deep roasted malts, maybe a hint of smoke in the aroma. Very rich flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, earthiness and sweet cream. Medium bodied that gives way to a bitter finish.

1/1/12. 500mL bottle. Black pour with a nice, thick tan head that cuts in half but sticks and laces everywhere. Rich aroma of bold, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and just a hint of sourness. Really tasty flavor that includes rich dark chocolates, milk chocolate, cream, grains, burnt caramel, and more. Yuuuuummmm. Luxurious smooth, creamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2012 Bottle shared with my brother on NYE
Pours almost black, tanned head. Smells of caramel, toffee, some coffee and roasted malts. Malty body good sweetness, also some liqorice. Dry mouthfeel that leads on to a nice bitter finish
Draft. Blackish beer with a big tan head. Chocolate and light malt aroma. Chocolate and light roast flavor with light toffee. Medium bodied. Chocolate and light roast lingers with light toffee.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Vanilla and chocolate notes. Moderate biter nice roasted flavor with nice vanilla notes. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Oh and I HATE the label!

Bottle.  A dark brown pour with a tan head that is big.  Nice chocolate on the nose along with some rye grain and ash tray.  The first thing I taste is the nice hop bite and that is quickly followed with roasted notes.  Coffee and chocolate balance well.  The aftertaste is, again, those hops.  They are bitter and fruity with some sulfur.  They also add some brightness to a beer that is dark and roasty.  There is a lot on top of the hops but they seem more complex than common European varieties.  This beer has nice complexity and balance.  Not only that, but it is just plain good.

A bit of a smoky touch touch this porter adds some originality to the overall drink. Flavor has a decently roasty malt presence as well. Nice creamy texture on the finish. Reminds me a lot of a melted milk chocolate candy. Right amount of sweetness. Smooth like a porter but with the complexity and originality of an impy stout.

Pours a deep, warm sable just a hair above black with a very thick and rather persistent tan head. Strong, smoky aroma has notes of roast coffee, licorice and semi-sweet chocolate. Bold flavor has a smoky overtone and includes coffee, licorice and chocolate tones plus a bitter hoppy note and more than a hint of sweetness. Full-bodied texture is smooth and quite fizzy, leaving a smoky, chocolaty finish. If this is not the best porter I have ever had, it is certainly one of the best. Keep up the good work, Mikkeller!

500 ml bottle shared by Doodler (thanks Scott) poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, bitter chocolate and charcoal. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, bitter chocolate and earthiness with a smooth lingering bitter chocolate finish.

On the Second Day of Christmas 2011 the beer gods gave to me...  A mighty fine imperial porter.  Pours a dark brown color with a creamy foam caramel head.      Aroma of heavy roast and caramel with hints of candi sugar, citrus and earthiness.  A sweet caramel taste with nice hop hit and some roastiness on the finish.  Excellent.

50cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Black colour, beige brown head. Aroma of mostly soft vanilla, cream, some brown sugar, dark fruits and liquorice. Flavour is medium sweet, vanilla, a bit of molasses,  liquorice, earth, coffee/moccha, some alcohol, hard roasted malts, bitter roasted finish. Light to medium bodied. Nice, tasty, couldve used a bit more body considering ABV.
Color oscuro negro con espuma densa.Aromas a cafe, maltas, lupulo y notas de alcohol.sabor denso sutilmente tostado.una buena porter

500ml bottle.

Pours a dark chocolate brown with a thick creamy tan head that sits on top as a 2 inch head for ages.

Aroma is very roasty ith lots of dark chocolate malts, cocoa powder and hints of espresso beans.  Maybe even a hint of smoke with some light oak notes.

Taste isnt quite as robust as the aroma.  There are sweet chocolate notes and roasted dark malts.  There may be a little more green hops as well but the coffee and cocoa powder are more subtle.

Mouthfeel is smooth and fairly light bodied for the style, a tad watery even.

This is a nice porter but its not quite up to the standard of the Hill Farmstead Everett I had last night.  Good but not great.

Draught at Ørsted, CopenhagenBlack color, with a small beige creamy head. Strong aroma, the story doesnt say, but with whisky and oak, then roasted malt, and cardboard. Smooth mouthfeel, with a correct body structure; strong flavor of roasted malt, chocolate and some caramel; there is some cardboard too and a quite evident whiskey trait; later there is a too high medicinal note; correct bitterness, although in the end some of it (maybe too much of it) comes from the roasted malt; liquorice too in the final.Pleasant non-Porter, with some glitch.

Bottle.Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt,roasted malt, burnt notes, nuts and chocolate. Flavor is sweet and roasted with some chocolate, malt, caramel, fruitiness, nuts and yeast. Medium body, average carbonation. Really nice porter .

Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. Looking more or less black in color, with a small, dense, brown head. Roasted malts, coffee, licorice, some alcohol and piney hops on the nose. The flavor is rather coffee-ish and coffee-like, with a nice piney bitterness. Some licorice. Full-bodied and a bit heavy on the carbonation. Roasted, bitter finish with coffee. A very nice porter, thats for sure. Wouldnt mind drinking more of this. Several times. 111112

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours very, very dark brown with a medium lightly tanned head. Dies down after a little while and leaves some big lacing all over. Aroma is lightly roasted coffee beans and dark cocoa powder. There is a slight bourbon undertone which runs through the aroma and adds a touch of vanilla essence. Taste is big on dark chocolate and vanilla. A touch of cocoa powder, coffee and wood in there as well. Very very good beer

Pitch black coloured. Small dense brown head. Aroma of cocao, coffee, roast, brown sugar and liqourice. Flavour of roast, chocolate, grass, sweetness, some herbs and liqourice. Medium to full bodied. Roasty bitter end.

Bottle 50cl. Black beer with light brown head, good lasting and lacing, creamy. Aroma is toasted, roasted, black coffee, dark chocolate, wood. Flavour is similar to dark coffee, with a minimal hints to burnt sweet malts On palate results moderate bittery. Well balanced, medium carbonation and medium to full body. Oily feel.

En botella.Muy  poca espuma con un poco de retencion.aromas a cafe azucar,licor...En boca muy cafetera,roast...Nivel de lúpulo bajo ,aunque perceptible.

On tap @ Mikkeller Bar. The aroma has coffee beans, roast, some liquorice, toffee. Black coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is bitter, roasted, has coffee, hint of chocolate. Dry finish, very clean. Nice one.

500ml bottle carried back home from Ølbutikken in Copenhagen a few months ago. Steady brownish head covering a near-black body with a russet shade. Spotty lacing to the glass. Characteristic aroma of chocolate malts, inviting. Blended taste of brown and black malts displaying chocolate, anise and dusty hops leading to a very smooth bitter ending. Perfect on a lazy Saturday afternoon at home in Tromsø, 01.10.2011.

Bottle, it pours pitch black with a medium off white head..... the aroma is coffee, roasty, tobacco and licorice... the flavor is dark fruit, roasted malt and coffee.... medium body... nice smooth mouthfeel with a bit alcohol finish....

Draught at CASK Pub and Kitchen, London. Black color. Sweet aroma of coffee and licorice. Sweet and roasty flavor with coffee, raisins and licorice. Very full body and very filling. Some rough alcohol is coming through but this is still quite enjoyable.

500ml bottle. Head quckly diminishes. Lovely off black colour. Lots of suspended yeast (maybe a bad pour - more practice). Love the aroma, complex chocolate toffee. Taste mellows after first few sips. Slight alcohol kick at the end. Solid.

Bottle  This beer rocks! Pours murky and dark brown with a small, creamy, taupe head. Good retention. Nutty, milk chocolate aroma with a gentle splash of espresso. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and tingly carbonation. Robust flavors of dark chocolate, charcoal, espresso and overly roasted tree nuts. Not sweet; leans bitter, burnt and acrid. Finishes much the same. Very reminiscent of CCB Puppys Breath Porter. World class beer provided by Plovmand!

Bottle. Nice lacy dark brown head on black beer. Fragrant nose of berries, chocolate, coffee. Sweet and fruity, with lightish roast and chocolate. Relatively light. Nice tartness. Mild, rather sweet, nice stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2012 Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is toffee, vanilla, caramel, toasted malts, coffee, liquorice, chocolate and general textbook porter aroma. Taste has roasted bitter coffee, english liquorice, hops, toffee, dark roasted malts leading to a dry end. A mellow and nice balanced porter..
Bottle. Black with small light brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, little smoke, hops, bitter, medium liquorice and medium sweet.
Draught at The Craft Beer & Co in London august 2011. Dark with a fluffty head. Coffee, chocolate roasted aroma. Sweet flavor with a nice licorice touch and some tar. Nice:-)

Nose is heavy roasted caramel, mahogany, cane sugar, weak iron, feel is broad, carb is mediumlow, taste is decent mediumheavy bitter hops throughout, heavy roasted malt, sweet port notes, warm alcohol, cork.

500ml bottle, beersofeurope.com. Well, where do I start? From the pour, which started quite flat, this deeply tan coffee coloured head bubbled into life and its retaining well, as I get about a third of the way down my pint glass. This is a stunning beer. All the heavy roast malt characteristics you could want in a porter, but then a faintly spicy , but noticeable, hop note creeps in to give a great balance. On the tongue its smooth, rich and so fully flavoured. Theres liquid chocolate in the finish and the aftertaste is a myriad of dark complex flavours. Mouthfeel is absolutely fasntastic and it is well coated. One of the finest Ive tasted and, yet again,Aa beer that really belies its ABV. Almost unnoticeable.

Bottle that I picked up at Beers of Europe, consumed at my mums, Worcester, 16.09.11   Pours black with a beige head. Has that typical Mikkeller flavour running through it, dificult to describe that exactly but I sort of know it when I taste it. Lovely porter though it has to be said that this is more smoother, indulgent and refined that a typical porter that I would be used to in the UK. Some smooth cappucinno coffee, and coffee ice cream on the nose. Like I suggest this is maybe not exactly the best example of the style but its a damn fine beer nonetheless.  A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15  3.8

Bottle.  Blackish brown beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is deeply roasted and bitter coffee, and the fllavour is very bitter with a full roasted espresso coffee body and finish .  Overall a very deep and robustly flavoured bitter and coffee flavoured strong porter.

Medium beige head.  Nearly opaque black body goes deep dark red
at edges.  Strong roasty dusty licorice aroma with spicy wooden
lacquer notes.  Sweet-dryish roasty earthy dusty taste with
toffee and pine needle notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel
with faint heat. Dryish chocolatey toffee and roasty dusty
aftertaste with licorice and alcohol notes.  Also very faint
acidity that blends in very well. Fantastically clear and vivid.
Harmonic and clean.  Perhaps the best porter Ive ever had.  This
beer has everything. (0.5l bottle, Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

500 ml. bottle from the amazing Kihoskh, Copenhagen. Pitch black "colour" with a tanned, medium sized, stable head. This beer has all the typical porter characteristics: Coffee malt aromas, lots of toast, chocolate and roasted, Nice! Complex flavor composition: Sweet from the chocolate malts, also some bitterness from hops, and roasted malts. Medium body with an oliy texture and soft carbonation. Nice, delicious long lasting finish with honey, roasted and chocolate notes. A really, really good beer, but when it comes to Danish porters, the Thisted Limfjords Porter to a quarter of the price is still unbeaten!
Bottle. Black pour, thick tan head. Aroma full of burnt malts, roasty and with coffee and licorice. Flavor is bitter, thick roasted and with some floral hops and licorice. Thick body. Nice brew.
Dark, dark brown pour. Head disappeared fast. Chocolate, liquorice, and malt in the aroma, delicate bitterness finishes the sweet taste. Stay classy.

Big, beautiful black pour. It might be brown, but I cant get any light through it to see. Starts out with a fairly large tan head. This quickly fades down to a thin layer of foam. Plenty of lacing left behind. Giant chocolate and coffee aroma. A bit of hops. Mostly chocolate and roasted grains though. Big chocolate and malty mouth. A slight bitterness and hop taste. Nice bitter aftertaste. Nice creamy mouthfeel, mixed with a slight bitterness and sweetness. Beautiful porter.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2014 Bottle. Black. Small head over the average body. Â Heavy roasted cereals. Bitter dry slight burnt notes. No head. Black oily. Coffe licorice notes. Dry bitter finish. No doubt a lot of hops as well. Retasted 20/5. Home on the terrace match with wÃ¼rst und gemÃ¼se. One finger head. Intense bitter-dryness.

Aroma is roasty malt, coffee and salty liquorice.
Flavour as well. Lazy rate, very good beer.

Draught @ Craft Beer Co., London
Rated on 20110720.
Pours pitch black with small head. Lots of vanilla, chocolate and honey on the nose. Vanilla and dry ashy chocolate on the flavor as well. Balanced and very smooth palate.
5326
Draught at Cask Pub & Kitchen, London. Black with creamy beige head. Dark chocolate aroma with notes of liquorice and violet. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry to medium dry, medium bitterness.

Pours darkest black. Thin brown minimal head. Nose is roasted malt, chocolate and coffee, but with minerals. Taste is nice chocolate, subtle coffee, little bitter on the finish. Oily in the mouth, little smokiness. Very nicely balanced.

tap at craft beer co ... deep dark black ... creamy tan head ... softy dark malts nose ... little over cold ... soft roast malt ...dark toffee malts ... soft chocolate ... mellow roast ... ovaltine ... but mostly dark roast

Cask @ pre GBBF 2011. A black colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma of roasted malts with coffee and fruits. The taste is a little bitter, some coffee, fruits and some alcohol. The aftertaste is bitter with notes of coffee with sweet.

23rd July 2011On tap at Craft Beer. Opaque black beer, short lived tan head. Smooth fresh dark malt. Minerals but no roast or bitterness. A little lactose sweetness. Well maybe a trace of roast then but very mild! Trace of smoke. Semi dry finish. Just a very nice Porter!

Draught at Craft Beer Co, London. Black beer, brown head. Roasted licorice aroma, smoked, coffee, dark chocolate, a bit oily. Salty flavor, coffee, licorice, tar, dark chocolate, viol, oily, hoppy. Bitter finish with licorice and coffee.

500ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pours black with a medium creamy head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and caramel. Taste is quite creamy and slightly sweet with notes of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Smooth, a bit bitter finish. Well balanced, tasty.

50 cl bottle @ EEIPAF. No BBE info
Great, intensive and roasted aroma with coffee. Flavour has lots of coffee, a lot of roastiness and hints of chocolate. Some harshness in the aftertaste. Anyway, great porter for a coffee lover like me.

500 ml bottle.
Pours a pitch black colour with a large, creamy head with good retention. Aroma of coffee, milk chocolate and some toffee. Flavour of roasted malts, coffee, milk chocolate with some floral hops. Very smooth bodied and a roasty, coffee, chocolate finish. Extremely well balanced.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Pours brown without any head.
